DFedSat: Communication-Efficient and Robust Decentralized Federated Learning for
LEO Satellite Constellations

Minghao Yang, Jingjing Zhang, Shengyun Liu Minghao Yang and Jingjing Zhang are with the Department of Communication Science and Engineering, Fudan University, Shanghai, China. Shengyun Liu is with the School of Electronic, Information and Electrical Engineering, Shanghai Jiao Tong University, Shanghai, China (e-mail: 23210720070@m.fudan.edu.cn, jingjingzhang@fudan.edu.cn, shengyun.liu@sjtu.edu.cn). (Corresponding author: Jingjing Zhang)
Abstract

Low Earth Orbit (LEO) satellites play a crucial role in the development of 6G mobile networks and space-air-ground integrated systems. Recent advancements in space technology have empowered LEO satellites with the capability to run AI applications. However, centralized approaches, where ground stations (GSs) act as servers and satellites as clients, often encounter slow convergence and inefficiencies due to intermittent connectivity between satellites and GSs. In contrast, decentralized federated learning (DFL) offers a promising alternative by facilitating direct communication between satellites (clients) via inter-satellite links (ISLs). However, inter-plane ISLs connecting satellites from different orbital planes are dynamic due to Doppler shifts and pointing limitations. This could impact model propagation and lead to slower convergence. To mitigate these issues, we propose DFedSat, a fully decentralized federated learning framework tailored for LEO satellites. DFedSat accelerates the training process by employing two adaptive mechanisms for intra-plane and inter-plane model aggregation, respectively. Furthermore, a self-compensation mechanism is integrated to enhance the robustness of inter-plane ISLs against transmission failure. Additionally, we derive the sublinear convergence rate for the non-convex case of DFedSat. Extensive experimental results demonstrate DFedSat’s superiority over other DFL baselines regarding convergence rate, communication efficiency, and resilience to unreliable links.

Index Terms:
Decentralized federated learning, Low Earth Orbit (LEO) satellites, gossip, robustness.

I Introduction

Satellite communication technology is poised to become a key component of the future integrated air, space, and ground network, attracting significant interest from industry giants such as SpaceX and Amazon, as well as governmental organizations like ESA and NASA [1]. This enthusiasm has driven the deployment of numerous Low Earth Orbit (LEO) satellites. Advancements in satellite hardware have empowered LEO satellites with enhanced cameras, processors, and antennas, enabling the collection of extensive Earth imagery and sensor data [2, 3]. Leveraging machine learning (ML) techniques to analyze these large datasets can provide valuable insights for a wide range of applications, including urban planning, weather forecasting, climate change research, and disaster management [4, 5, 6].

However, the conventional methodology of transferring raw image data to a central server, such as a ground station (GS), for training a centralized ML model is impractical due to limited bandwidth and data privacy concerns. Federated learning (FL) offers a promising solution to these challenges [7]. Within the framework of FL, each client (satellite) independently updates ML models based on its local dataset, transmitting only model parameters in each iteration. This approach can significantly reduce bandwidth requirements while preserving data privacy.

Although research on satellite FL is still in its early stages, several studies have made significant progress. The traditional synchronous FL method, FedAvg [7], is applied to LEO constellations, demonstrating the benefits of combining satellite networks and FL [8]. However, the short, sporadic, and irregular communication windows between GS and satellites result in very slow convergence. To enhance the performance in satellite FL systems, researchers apply ISLs and clustering strategies [9, 10, 11, 12]. Additionally, High-Altitude Platforms (HAPs) are introduced as relays to facilitate faster convergence [13, 14]. To circumvent the limitations imposed by communication windows, asynchronous FL is applied to LEO constellations [15]. However, asynchronous FL encounters the issue of gradient staleness, where outdated gradients can significantly impair model convergence and overall performance [16]. Recent works attempt to mitigate this impact through rational scheduling [17], adjusting the weights of the outdated gradients[18, 19], optimizing the transmission delay to reduce the outdated gradients[20], and employing gradient compensation [21].

In contrast to centralized federated learning (CFL), decentralized federated learning (DFL) overcomes the limitations of the parameter-server structure [22]. The authors of [23] introduce refinements to DFL by employing multiple local iterations and quantization techniques to reduce communication costs, yielding promising convergence results, particularly in convex scenarios. More recent contributions, such as [24], propose methodologies like DFedSAM, which leverages gradient perturbation to generate local flat models via sharpness-aware minimization (SAM). This method achieves optimal results in current DFL-related work. In the decentralized satellite FL framework, model parameters are transmitted between satellites through inter-satellite links (ISLs). Research on decentralized satellite FL (DSFL) remains relatively sparse so far. Wu et al. propose DSFL [25], which uses intra-plane and inter-plane satellite links to accomplish model aggregation. It designs an inter-satellite routing algorithm to aggregate the model onto a specific satellite. Most recently, [26] proposes an offloading-assisted DSFL framework, aiming to speed up convergence by facilitating data sharing among satellites to counteract the effects of heterogeneous data distribution. However, they assume ideally that the transmission must be 100% successful.

In real satellite communication networks, inter-plane ISLs are usually unreliable due to two main factors:

∙∙\bullet Doppler Shift: The rapid relative movement of satellites induces a significant, time-varying Doppler shift that impairs communication between satellites [27, 28, 29].

∙∙\bullet Pointing Errors: Misalignment of the transceivers leads to pointing errors, resulting in additional performance degradation and even link failure [30, 31, 32].

The impact of such unreliability can result in the loss of the received signal, or even slow convergence rates and low communication efficiency. Therefore, for a more realistic study of DSFL, the instability of inter-plane ISLs must be considered. To the best of our knowledge, this is the first work to address this instability in DSFL. This study aims to bridge this gap by considering non-idealized ISLs in the LEO constellation and tailoring the DSFL framework for efficient and robust operation. To this end, we develop a robust and fully decentralized satellite FL framework tailored to LEO satellite networks, namely DFedSat. To address the issue of unreliable inter-plane transmission, DFedSat employs a robust model self-compensation mechanism to handle packet loss and transmission errors that may occur during model transmission.

Our main contributions are summarized as follows.

∙∙\bullet We present DFedSat, a fully decentralized framework for satellite federated learning. To the best of our knowledge, this is the first work to address the instability of ISLs in decentralized satellite FL. The proposed framework enables distributed consensus of models by implementing two specialized mechanisms tailored for intra-plane and inter-plane model exchanges.

∙∙\bullet To mitigate the adverse effects of unreliable inter-plane ISLs on the model transfer process, we introduce a self-compensation mechanism within our framework. This approach not only enhances the robustness of the inter-plane communication but also mitigates the overall communication overhead by reducing the need for retransmissions.

∙∙\bullet We present the sublinear convergence rate for DFedSat in a non-convex setting under conditions of unreliable communication. Our findings indicate that DFedSat attains an asymptotic convergence rate comparable to that of the standard DFL algorithm in scenarios with perfect communication. This establishes the robustness and reliability of DFedSat, particularly in the presence of instabilities in inter-plane ISLs.

∙∙\bullet We conduct extensive experiments to demonstrate the efficacy of DFedSat. Experimental results show that DFedSat exhibits higher performance and communication efficiency compared to the benchmark strategies. Furthermore, it demonstrates superior performance with high robustness under unreliable communication conditions.

The remainder of this paper is organized as follows. Section II presents the system model for LEO Satellite Constellations and the framework of DFL. Section III elaborates on the proposed DFedSat algorithm, specifically designed for the LEO constellations. Section IV provides a convergence analysis of DFedSat. Numerical results are discussed in Section V, and conclusions are drawn in Section VI.

II System Model

In this section, we introduce the system model of the LEO system. This includes the architecture of the LEO Constellations, the satellite communication model, the satellite computing model within a DFL framework, and the ISL packet failure model.

II-A LEO Satellite Constellations

We consider a general LEO constellation consisting of M𝑀M planes, each with K𝐾K satellites. The satellites are represented by the set 𝒩={s11,…,s1​K,…,sM​1,…,sM​K}𝒩subscript𝑠11…subscript𝑠1𝐾…subscript𝑠𝑀1…subscript𝑠𝑀𝐾\mathcal{N}=\{s_{11},...,s_{1K},...,s_{M1},...,s_{MK}\}, where each element sm​ksubscript𝑠𝑚𝑘s_{mk} denotes the k𝑘k-th satellite in the m𝑚m-th plane. These satellites are evenly spaced by π/M𝜋𝑀\pi/M radians within each plane, ensuring an equal number of satellites per plane.

Each LEO satellite is equipped with four antennas, two on the pitch axis and two on the roll axis, facilitating unicast satellite-to-satellite communication. This configuration provides four ISLs: two intra-plane ISLs for communication within the same orbital plane and two inter-plane ISLs for communication with satellites in different planes. Consequently, we can model the LEO satellite network as a 2D-torus undirected graph 𝒢=(𝒩,ℰ)𝒢𝒩ℰ\mathcal{G}=(\mathcal{N},\mathcal{E}), where we have |𝒩|=M​K𝒩𝑀𝐾|\mathcal{N}|=MK and ℰℰ\mathcal{E} represents the set of ISLs. An illustration of the LEO system is shown in Fig. 1.

II-B Satellite Communication Model

Compared to radio frequency communication, free-space optical communication is more suitable for interplanetary communication scenarios due to its higher data rate and stronger anti-jamming capabilities. Therefore, we consider laser communication for ISLs between satellites. The received signal power PRsubscript𝑃𝑅P_{R} can be mathematically expressed as

PR=PT​ηT​GT​ηR​GR​LT​LR​(λ4​π​l)2,subscript𝑃𝑅subscript𝑃𝑇subscript𝜂𝑇subscript𝐺𝑇subscript𝜂𝑅subscript𝐺𝑅subscript𝐿𝑇subscript𝐿𝑅superscript𝜆4𝜋𝑙2P_{R}=P_{T}\eta_{T}G_{T}\eta_{R}G_{R}L_{T}L_{R}\biggl{(}\frac{\lambda}{4\pi l}\biggr{)}^{2}, (1)

where PTsubscript𝑃𝑇P_{T} is the transmitting optical power, ηTsubscript𝜂𝑇\eta_{T} and GTsubscript𝐺𝑇G_{T} are the transmitting optical efficiency and telescope gains, ηRsubscript𝜂𝑅\eta_{R} and GRsubscript𝐺𝑅G_{R} are the receiving optical efficiency and telescope gains, and LTsubscript𝐿𝑇L_{T} and LRsubscript𝐿𝑅L_{R} are the transmitter and receiver pointing loss factors, respectively[33]. λ𝜆\lambda is the wavelength and l𝑙l is the distance between the transmitter and receiver. If the beam is Gaussian, the pointing loss factors can be expressed as

LT=e−GT​θT2,LR=e−GR​θR2,formulae-sequencesubscript𝐿𝑇superscript𝑒subscript𝐺𝑇superscriptsubscript𝜃𝑇2subscript𝐿𝑅superscript𝑒subscript𝐺𝑅superscriptsubscript𝜃𝑅2L_{T}=e^{-G_{T}\theta_{T}^{2}},L_{R}=e^{-G_{R}\theta_{R}^{2}}, (2)

where θTsubscript𝜃𝑇\theta_{T} and θRsubscript𝜃𝑅\theta_{R} are the transmitter and receiver radial pointing error angles, respectively. Assuming the transmitter and receiver use telescopes with the same diameter D𝐷D, we have

GT=GR=G≈(π​Dλ)2.subscript𝐺𝑇subscript𝐺𝑅𝐺superscript𝜋𝐷𝜆2G_{T}=G_{R}=G\approx\bigg{(}{\frac{\pi D}{\lambda}}\bigg{)}^{2}. (3)

Substituting this into Eq. (1), we can obtain

PR=PT​ηT​ηR​G2​e−G​(θT2+θR2)​(λ4​π​l)2,subscript𝑃𝑅subscript𝑃𝑇subscript𝜂𝑇subscript𝜂𝑅superscript𝐺2superscript𝑒𝐺superscriptsubscript𝜃𝑇2superscriptsubscript𝜃𝑅2superscript𝜆4𝜋𝑙2P_{R}=P_{T}\eta_{T}\eta_{R}G^{2}e^{-G(\theta_{T}^{2}+\theta_{R}^{2})}\biggl{(}\frac{\lambda}{4\pi l}\biggr{)}^{2}, (4)

where θT2+θR2superscriptsubscript𝜃𝑇2superscriptsubscript𝜃𝑅2\theta_{T}^{2}+\theta_{R}^{2} follows a chi-squared distribution with four degrees of freedom, since θTsubscript𝜃𝑇\theta_{T} and θRsubscript𝜃𝑅\theta_{R} each encompass two normal processes (azimuth and elevation) [33]. Assuming the standard deviation of the pointing error angles is equal, i.e., σT=σR=σθsubscript𝜎𝑇subscript𝜎𝑅subscript𝜎𝜃\sigma_{T}=\sigma_{R}=\sigma_{\theta}, the sum θT2+θR2superscriptsubscript𝜃𝑇2superscriptsubscript𝜃𝑅2\theta_{T}^{2}+\theta_{R}^{2} follows a gamma distribution Γ∼{2,12​σθ2}similar-toΓ212superscriptsubscript𝜎𝜃2\Gamma\sim\{2,\frac{1}{2\sigma_{\theta}^{2}}\}.

Furthermore, we analyze three primary forms of noise present in a laser communication system: signal shot noise, dark current noise, and thermal-Johnson noise, each with their respective variances as follows:

σs​n2=2​q​Rp​PR​B,σd​c2=2​q​Id​B,σt​h2=4​kB​Tn​BRL,formulae-sequencesuperscriptsubscript𝜎𝑠𝑛22𝑞subscript𝑅𝑝subscript𝑃𝑅𝐵formulae-sequencesuperscriptsubscript𝜎𝑑𝑐22𝑞subscript𝐼𝑑𝐵superscriptsubscript𝜎𝑡ℎ24subscript𝑘𝐵subscript𝑇𝑛𝐵subscript𝑅𝐿\sigma_{{sn}}^{2}=2qR_{p}P_{R}B,~{}~{}\sigma_{{dc}}^{2}=2qI_{d}B,~{}~{}\sigma_{th}^{2}={\frac{4k_{B}T_{n}B}{R_{L}}}, (5)

where q𝑞q is the electron charge, Rpsubscript𝑅𝑝R_{p} is the responsivity, B𝐵B is the bandwidth, Idsubscript𝐼𝑑I_{d} is dark current, kBsubscript𝑘𝐵k_{B} is the Boltzmann constant, Tnsubscript𝑇𝑛T_{n} is noise temperature and RLsubscript𝑅𝐿R_{L} is the load resistance[34]. This yields the signal-to-noise ratio (SNR) for ISL given as

SNR=PRσd​c2+σt​h2+σs​n2.SNRsubscript𝑃𝑅superscriptsubscript𝜎𝑑𝑐2superscriptsubscript𝜎𝑡ℎ2superscriptsubscript𝜎𝑠𝑛2\mathrm{SNR}=\frac{P_{R}}{\sigma_{dc}^{2}+\sigma_{th}^{2}+\sigma_{sn}^{2}}. (6)

Hence, the achievable data rate is given by:

r=B​log2⁡(1+SNR).𝑟𝐵subscript21SNRr=B\log_{2}(1+\mathrm{SNR}). (7)

II-C Satellite Computing Model

We now present the DFL architecture within the aforementioned LEO constellation framework. In this setup, satellites function as clients, with each satellite sm​ksubscript𝑠𝑚𝑘s_{mk} maintaining a locally distributed dataset 𝒟m​ksubscript𝒟𝑚𝑘{\mathcal{D}_{mk}}. The objective is to collaboratively train a global ML model 𝐰𝐰\mathbf{w} using local data by minimizing the global loss function F​(𝐰)𝐹𝐰F\left(\mathbf{w}\right), defined as

min𝐰∈ℝdF​(𝐰)≜∑sm​k∈𝒩|𝒟m​k||𝒟|​fm​k​(𝐰),≜subscript𝐰superscriptℝ𝑑𝐹𝐰subscriptsubscript𝑠𝑚𝑘𝒩subscript𝒟𝑚𝑘𝒟subscript𝑓𝑚𝑘𝐰\mathop{\min}\limits_{\mathbf{w}\in\mathbb{R}^{d}}F\left(\mathbf{w}\right)\triangleq\sum\limits_{s_{mk}\in\mathcal{N}}\frac{|\mathcal{D}_{mk}|}{|\mathcal{D}|}{{f_{mk}}\left({\mathbf{w}}\right)}, (8)

where |𝒟|=∑sm​k∈𝒩|𝒟m​k|𝒟subscriptsubscript𝑠𝑚𝑘𝒩subscript𝒟𝑚𝑘|\mathcal{D}|=\sum_{s_{mk}\in\mathcal{N}}{|\mathcal{D}_{mk}|} is the total number of train data samples across all satellites. The local loss function fm​ksubscript𝑓𝑚𝑘f_{mk} is defined as:

fm​k​(𝐰)=1|𝒟m​k|​∑ξ∈𝒟m​kfm​k​(𝐰m​k,ξ),subscript𝑓𝑚𝑘𝐰1subscript𝒟𝑚𝑘subscript𝜉subscript𝒟𝑚𝑘subscript𝑓𝑚𝑘subscript𝐰𝑚𝑘𝜉{f_{mk}}\left(\mathbf{w}\right)=\frac{1}{{\left|{{\mathcal{D}_{mk}}}\right|}}\sum\limits_{\xi\in{\mathcal{D}_{mk}}}{{f_{mk}}}\left(\mathbf{w}_{mk},\xi\right), (9)

where fm​k,ξ​(𝐰m​k)subscript𝑓𝑚𝑘𝜉subscript𝐰𝑚𝑘{{f_{mk,\xi}}}\left(\mathbf{w}_{mk}\right) is the loss function at the data point ξ𝜉\xi for the local model 𝐰m​ksubscript𝐰𝑚𝑘\mathbf{w}_{mk} of satellite sm​ksubscript𝑠𝑚𝑘s_{mk}.

Particularly, at each training round t𝑡t, the following steps are executed:

1) Orbit computing: By setting 𝐰m​kt,0=𝐰m​ktsuperscriptsubscript𝐰𝑚𝑘𝑡0superscriptsubscript𝐰𝑚𝑘𝑡\mathbf{w}_{mk}^{t,0}=\mathbf{w}_{mk}^{t}, each satellite sm​ksubscript𝑠𝑚𝑘s_{mk} operates I𝐼I local epochs. The updating rule for stochastic gradient descent (SGD) is given as

𝐰m​kt,i+1=𝐰m​kt,i−η​∇f​(𝐰m​kt,i,ξti),i=0,1,…,I−1,formulae-sequencesuperscriptsubscript𝐰𝑚𝑘𝑡𝑖1superscriptsubscript𝐰𝑚𝑘𝑡𝑖𝜂∇𝑓superscriptsubscript𝐰𝑚𝑘𝑡𝑖superscriptsubscript𝜉𝑡𝑖𝑖01…𝐼1\mathbf{w}_{mk}^{t,i+1}=\mathbf{w}_{mk}^{t,i}-\eta\nabla f(\mathbf{w}_{mk}^{t,i},\xi_{t}^{i}),i=0,1,...,I-1, (10)

where η𝜂\eta is the learning rate and ∇f​(⋅)∇𝑓⋅\nabla f(\cdot) is the stochastic gradient of satellite sm​ksubscript𝑠𝑚𝑘s_{mk} with respect to the mini-batch ξtisuperscriptsubscript𝜉𝑡𝑖\xi_{t}^{i}, sampled from the local dataset 𝒟m​ksubscript𝒟𝑚𝑘{\mathcal{D}_{mk}}. As a result, each satellite sm​ksubscript𝑠𝑚𝑘s_{mk} obtains the updated local model 𝐰m​kt,Isuperscriptsubscript𝐰𝑚𝑘𝑡𝐼\mathbf{w}_{mk}^{t,I}.

2) Model consensus: Each satellite sm​ksubscript𝑠𝑚𝑘s_{mk} exchanges its updated local model 𝐰m​kt,Isuperscriptsubscript𝐰𝑚𝑘𝑡𝐼\mathbf{w}_{mk}^{t,I} with its neighbor satellites 𝒩m​ksubscript𝒩𝑚𝑘\mathcal{N}_{mk} via intra-plane and inter-plane ISLs. This process completes the model consensus step, given as:

𝐰m​kt+1=∑sn​j∈𝒩m​k|𝒟n​j||𝒟𝒩m​k|​𝐰n​jt,I,superscriptsubscript𝐰𝑚𝑘𝑡1subscriptsubscript𝑠𝑛𝑗subscript𝒩𝑚𝑘subscript𝒟𝑛𝑗subscript𝒟subscript𝒩𝑚𝑘subscriptsuperscript𝐰𝑡𝐼𝑛𝑗\mathbf{w}_{mk}^{t+1}=\sum_{s_{nj}\in\mathcal{N}_{mk}}\frac{|\mathcal{D}_{nj}|}{|\mathcal{D}_{\mathcal{N}_{mk}}|}\mathbf{w}^{t,I}_{nj}, (11)

Then, the next training round t+1𝑡1t+1 starts. This repeats until the prespecified termination criteria are met.

In the model consensus stage, the model exchange process can be characterized by the mixing matrix 𝐐𝐐\mathbf{Q}. Specifically, let 𝐖t+1/2=[𝐰11t,I,…,𝐰1​Kt,I,…,𝐰M​1t,I,…,𝐰M​Kt,I]⊤∈ℝM​K×dwsuperscript𝐖𝑡12superscriptsubscriptsuperscript𝐰𝑡𝐼11…subscriptsuperscript𝐰𝑡𝐼1𝐾…subscriptsuperscript𝐰𝑡𝐼𝑀1…subscriptsuperscript𝐰𝑡𝐼𝑀𝐾topsuperscriptℝ𝑀𝐾subscript𝑑𝑤\mathbf{W}^{t+1/2}=[\mathbf{w}^{t,I}_{11},...,\mathbf{w}^{t,I}_{1K},...,\mathbf{w}^{t,I}_{M1},...,\mathbf{w}^{t,I}_{MK}]^{\top}\in\mathbb{R}^{MK\times d_{w}} denote the updated model parameters of all satellites 𝒩𝒩\mathcal{N} in round t𝑡t, where dwsubscript𝑑𝑤d_{w} is the model dimension. The aggregated model 𝐖t+1=[𝐰11t+1,…,𝐰1​Kt+1,…,𝐰M​1t+1,…,𝐰M​Kt+1]⊤superscript𝐖𝑡1superscriptsubscriptsuperscript𝐰𝑡111…subscriptsuperscript𝐰𝑡11𝐾…subscriptsuperscript𝐰𝑡1𝑀1…subscriptsuperscript𝐰𝑡1𝑀𝐾top\mathbf{W}^{t+1}=[\mathbf{w}^{t+1}_{11},...,\mathbf{w}^{t+1}_{1K},...,\mathbf{w}^{t+1}_{M1},...,\mathbf{w}^{t+1}_{MK}]^{\top} can then be expressed as

𝐖t+1=𝐐𝐖t+1/2.superscript𝐖𝑡1superscript𝐐𝐖𝑡12\mathbf{W}^{t+1}=\mathbf{Q}\mathbf{W}^{t+1/2}. (12)

We recall the definition of the mixing matrix 𝐐𝐐\mathbf{Q}.

Definition 1. (Mixing matrix). The mixing matrix 𝐐=[qm​k,n​j]∈ℝM​K×M​K𝐐delimited-[]subscript𝑞𝑚𝑘𝑛𝑗superscriptℝ𝑀𝐾𝑀𝐾\mathbf{Q}=[q_{mk,nj}]\in\mathbb{R}^{MK\times MK} in the LEO satellite network graph 𝒢=(𝒩,ℰ)𝒢𝒩ℰ\mathcal{G}=(\mathcal{N},\mathcal{E}) is assumed to have the following properties:

∙∙\bullet Every entry of 𝐐𝐐\mathbf{Q} satisfies qm​k,n​j∈[0,1]subscript𝑞𝑚𝑘𝑛𝑗01q_{mk,nj}\in[0,1], if m​k≠n​j𝑚𝑘𝑛𝑗mk\neq nj and (m​k,n​j)∉ℰ𝑚𝑘𝑛𝑗ℰ(mk,nj)\notin\mathcal{E}, qm​k,n​j=0subscript𝑞𝑚𝑘𝑛𝑗0q_{mk,nj}=0, otherwise, qm​k,n​j=|𝒟n​j||𝒟𝒩m​k|subscript𝑞𝑚𝑘𝑛𝑗subscript𝒟𝑛𝑗subscript𝒟subscript𝒩𝑚𝑘q_{mk,nj}=\frac{|\mathcal{D}_{nj}|}{|\mathcal{D}_{\mathcal{N}_{mk}}|}.

∙∙\bullet 𝐐𝟏M​K=𝟏M​Ksubscript𝐐𝟏𝑀𝐾subscript1𝑀𝐾\mathbf{Q1}_{MK}=\mathbf{1}_{MK} and 𝐐=𝐐⊤𝐐superscript𝐐top\mathbf{Q}=\mathbf{Q}^{\top} where we have the vector 𝟏M​K=[1,1,…,1]⊤∈ℝM​Ksubscript1𝑀𝐾superscript11…1topsuperscriptℝ𝑀𝐾\mathbf{1}_{MK}=[1,1,...,1]^{\top}\in\mathbb{R}^{MK};

∙∙\bullet Denote its eigenvalues by 1=|λ1|>|λ2|≥…≥|λM​K|≥01subscript𝜆1subscript𝜆2…subscript𝜆𝑀𝐾01=|\lambda_{1}|>|\lambda_{2}|\geq...\geq|\lambda_{MK}|\geq 0 and then there exists a fixed constant λ:=max​{|λ2|,|λM​K|}assign𝜆maxsubscript𝜆2subscript𝜆𝑀𝐾\lambda:=\textrm{max}\{|\lambda_{2}|,|\lambda_{MK}|\} such that ‖𝐐−1M​K​𝟏M​K​𝟏M​K⊤‖2≤λsubscriptnorm𝐐1𝑀𝐾subscript1𝑀𝐾superscriptsubscript1𝑀𝐾top2𝜆\|\mathbf{Q}-\frac{1}{MK}\mathbf{1}_{MK}\mathbf{1}_{MK}^{\top}\|_{2}\leq\lambda.

The constant 1−λ1𝜆1-\lambda is referred to as the spectral gap of 𝐐𝐐\mathbf{Q}, serving as a measure of the graph’s connectivity. A well-connected graph is indicated by λ→0absent→𝜆0\lambda\xrightarrow{}0, implying 𝐐→1M​K​𝟏M​K​𝟏M​K⊤absent→𝐐1𝑀𝐾subscript1𝑀𝐾superscriptsubscript1𝑀𝐾top\mathbf{Q}\xrightarrow{}\frac{1}{MK}\mathbf{1}_{MK}\mathbf{1}_{MK}^{\top}, whereas a poorly connected graph corresponds to λ→1absent→𝜆1\lambda\xrightarrow{}1, implying 𝐐→𝐈absent→𝐐𝐈\mathbf{Q}\xrightarrow{}\mathbf{I}. The value of λ𝜆\lambda determines the convergence speed of the Markov chain introduced by the mixing matrix 𝐐𝐐\mathbf{Q} to a stable state, which signifies distributed consensus.

II-D ISL Packet Failure Model

The inter-plane ISLs between satellites in different planes are highly unstable due to Doppler shifts and pointing failures. To quantify the impact of this instability on model transmission, we consider a packet failure model and define the probability of successful transmission as follows:

p:=ℙ​[SNR>γt​h],assign𝑝ℙdelimited-[]SNRsubscript𝛾𝑡ℎp:=\mathbb{P}[\mathrm{SNR}>\gamma_{th}], (13)

where γt​hsubscript𝛾𝑡ℎ\gamma_{th} is the link SNR threshold. To this end, each local model parameter 𝐰m​kt,Isuperscriptsubscript𝐰𝑚𝑘𝑡𝐼\mathbf{w}_{mk}^{t,I} is partitioned into d𝑑d packets and transmitted sequentially. We denote the model packets sequence as 𝐰ˇ∈ℝdwd×dˇ𝐰superscriptℝsubscript𝑑𝑤𝑑𝑑\check{\mathbf{w}}\in\mathbb{R}^{\frac{d_{w}}{d}\times d}. Following the modeling of [35], the process of randomly receiving model packets is represented by a Bernoulli random vector 𝐦∈ℝd𝐦superscriptℝ𝑑\mathbf{m}\in\mathbb{R}^{d}, with each element 𝐦​[j]​∼i.i.d.​Bernoulli​(p),∀j∈[1,2,⋯,d]\mathbf{m}[j]\overset{i.i.d.}{\sim}\text{Bernoulli}(p),\forall j\in[1,2,\cdots,d]. Specifically, for any j𝑗j, we have

𝐦​[j]={1,with probabilityp,0,with probability1−p.𝐦delimited-[]𝑗cases1with probability𝑝0with probability1𝑝\mathbf{m}[j]=\begin{cases}{{1,\textrm{with probability}}}&p,\\ {{0,\textrm{with probability}}}&1-p.\\ \end{cases} (14)

As a result, the packets received by the receiver, which have been transmitted over inter-plane ISLs, can be represented as 𝐦⊙𝐰ˇdirect-product𝐦ˇ𝐰\mathbf{m}\odot\mathbf{\check{w}}.

III DFedSat

In this section, we introduce our proposed algorithm, DFedSat. The key innovation is the incorporation of a two-phase aggregation strategy in the model consensus stage to address the varying stability of ISLs, thereby enhancing the efficiency of the training process. Specifically, DFedSat employs an orbit reduce mechanism for intra-plane model synchronization. In contrast, for the volatile inter-plane ISLs, DFedSat applies a flexible gossip approach to manage model dissemination across different planes. This adaptive strategy not only facilitates model diffusion but also leverages the information gleaned from the preceding intra-plane synchronization, thereby accelerating model convergence.

Additionally, to mitigate the effects of packet failures due to the instability of inter-plane ISLs, DFedSat incorporates a model self-compensation mechanism during the inter-plane model dissemination phase. This feature leverages local parameters for adaptive self-compensation, significantly enhancing the system’s robustness.

III-A The design of DFedSat

The DFedSat procedure consists of two phases for each round t𝑡t: orbit computing and model consensus. The model consensus phase, guided by an adaptive aggregation mechanism, is further divided into two stages: intra-plane model synchronization, and inter-plane model dissemination. The pipeline of DFedSat is illustrated in Fig. 2, and the detailed steps are outlined in Algorithm 1. The specific procedures for each round t𝑡t in DFedSat are as follows.

1) Orbit Computing. Each satellite performs I𝐼I local epochs via (10). In DFedSat, the updated model parameters serve as the starting point for the subsequent two-stage model consensus. Thus, we denote 𝐰m​kt,Isubscriptsuperscript𝐰𝑡𝐼𝑚𝑘\mathbf{w}^{t,I}_{mk} as 𝐰m​kt+1/3subscriptsuperscript𝐰𝑡13𝑚𝑘\mathbf{w}^{t+1/3}_{mk}, and hence represent the updated parameters as 𝐖t+1/3=[𝐰11t+1/3,…,𝐰1​Kt+1/3,…,𝐰M​1t+1/3,…,𝐰M​Kt+1/3]⊤superscript𝐖𝑡13superscriptsubscriptsuperscript𝐰𝑡1311…subscriptsuperscript𝐰𝑡131𝐾…subscriptsuperscript𝐰𝑡13𝑀1…subscriptsuperscript𝐰𝑡13𝑀𝐾top\mathbf{W}^{t+1/3}=[\mathbf{w}^{t+1/3}_{11},...,\mathbf{w}^{t+1/3}_{1K},...,\mathbf{w}^{t+1/3}_{M1},...,\mathbf{w}^{t+1/3}_{MK}]^{\top}.

2) Model Consensus. The entire phase encompasses intra-plane model synchronization using the ring all-reduce mechanism [36], referred to as orbit reduce, and inter-plane model dissemination employing a flexible gossip approach.

a) Intra-plane model synchronization. In this stage, each plane m𝑚m with K𝐾K satellites operates independently in a ring topology. Our objective is for each satellite sm​ksubscript𝑠𝑚𝑘s_{mk} to ultimately acquire the parameters from all other satellites in its plane m𝑚m, thereby achieving model synchronization:

𝐰m​kt+2/3=∑j=1Kqm​k,m​ja∗𝐰m​jt+1/3,∀m,k,superscriptsubscript𝐰𝑚𝑘𝑡23superscriptsubscript𝑗1𝐾superscriptsubscript𝑞𝑚𝑘𝑚𝑗𝑎superscriptsubscript𝐰𝑚𝑗𝑡13for-all𝑚𝑘\displaystyle\mathbf{w}_{mk}^{t+2/3}=\sum\limits_{j=1}^{K}q_{mk,mj}^{a}*\mathbf{w}_{mj}^{t+1/3},\forall m,k, (15)

where qm​k,m​ja=|𝒟|m​j|𝒟|m=|𝒟m​j|∑k=1K|𝒟m​k|superscriptsubscript𝑞𝑚𝑘𝑚𝑗𝑎subscript𝒟𝑚𝑗subscript𝒟𝑚subscript𝒟𝑚𝑗superscriptsubscript𝑘1𝐾subscript𝒟𝑚𝑘q_{mk,mj}^{a}=\frac{|\mathcal{D}|_{mj}}{|\mathcal{D}|_{m}}=\frac{|\mathcal{D}_{mj}|}{\sum_{k=1}^{K}|\mathcal{D}_{mk}|} is the intra-plane mixing weight and |𝒟|msubscript𝒟𝑚|\mathcal{D}|_{m} is the total number of training data samples held by all satellites in orbit m𝑚m.

Orbit reduce begins with the scatter-reduce operation. Each satellite sm​ksubscript𝑠𝑚𝑘s_{mk} in plane m𝑚m splits its local model parameter 𝐰m​kt+1/3subscriptsuperscript𝐰𝑡13𝑚𝑘\mathbf{w}^{t+1/3}_{mk} into K𝐾K equally-sized segments and then performs K−1𝐾1K-1 communication iterations. Specifically, in each iteration, each satellite sm​ksubscript𝑠𝑚𝑘s_{mk} scatters one segment to the subsequent satellite while accumulating the segment received from the preceding one. After K−1𝐾1K-1 iterations, each satellite sm​ksubscript𝑠𝑚𝑘s_{mk} holds one unique segment of 𝐰m​kt+2/3superscriptsubscript𝐰𝑚𝑘𝑡23\mathbf{w}_{mk}^{t+2/3}. Next, each satellite undergoes K−1𝐾1K-1 communication iterations of the all-gather operation. During this process, each satellite replaces its corresponding segment with the received segment instead of accumulating them. At the end, each satellite sm​ksubscript𝑠𝑚𝑘s_{mk} concatenates all segments to obtain the intra-plane synchronized model 𝐰m​kt+2/3superscriptsubscript𝐰𝑚𝑘𝑡23\mathbf{w}_{mk}^{t+2/3}. An example of intra-plane model synchronization for K=3𝐾3K=3 satellites via orbit reduce is illustrated in Fig. 3.

Based on aforementioned description, the intra-plane mixing matrix 𝐐a=[qm​k,n​ja]∈ℝM​K×M​Ksubscript𝐐𝑎delimited-[]subscriptsuperscript𝑞𝑎𝑚𝑘𝑛𝑗superscriptℝ𝑀𝐾𝑀𝐾\mathbf{Q}_{a}=[q^{a}_{mk,nj}]\in\mathbb{R}^{MK\times MK} can be expressed as:

𝐐a=(𝐐1′𝟎⋯𝟎𝟎𝐐2′⋯𝟎⋮⋮⋱⋮𝟎𝟎⋯𝐐M′),subscript𝐐𝑎subscriptsuperscript𝐐′10⋯00subscriptsuperscript𝐐′2⋯0⋮⋮⋱⋮00⋯subscriptsuperscript𝐐′𝑀\mathbf{Q}_{a}=\left(\begin{array}[]{c c c c }{{{\mathbf{Q}^{{}^{\prime}}_{1}}}}&{{{\mathbf{0}}}}&{{{\cdots}}}&{{{\mathbf{0}}}}\\ {{{\mathbf{0}}}}&{{{\mathbf{Q}^{{}^{\prime}}_{2}}}}&{{{\cdots}}}&{{{\mathbf{0}}}}\\ {{{\vdots}}}&{{{\vdots}}}&{{{\ddots}}}&{{{\vdots}}}\\ {{{\mathbf{0}}}}&{{{\mathbf{0}}}}&{{{\cdots}}}&{{{\mathbf{Q}^{{}^{\prime}}_{M}}}}\\ \end{array}\right), (16)

where 𝐐m′=[qm​k,m​ja]∈ℝK×Ksubscriptsuperscript𝐐′𝑚delimited-[]subscriptsuperscript𝑞𝑎𝑚𝑘𝑚𝑗superscriptℝ𝐾𝐾\mathbf{Q}^{{}^{\prime}}_{m}=[q^{a}_{mk,mj}]\in\mathbb{R}^{K\times K} for 1≤m≤M1𝑚𝑀1\leq m\leq M. 𝐐m′subscriptsuperscript𝐐′𝑚\mathbf{Q}^{{}^{\prime}}_{m} represents the mixing matrix of plane m𝑚m. Then, the intra-plane synchronized model vector 𝐖t+2/3superscript𝐖𝑡23\mathbf{W}^{t+2/3} after orbit reduce can be express as

𝐖t+2/3=𝐐a​𝐖t+1/3.superscript𝐖𝑡23subscript𝐐𝑎superscript𝐖𝑡13\mathbf{W}^{t+2/3}=\mathbf{Q}_{a}\mathbf{W}^{t+1/3}. (17)

Remark 1. Note that each satellite sm​ksubscript𝑠𝑚𝑘s_{mk} performs a total of 2​K−22𝐾22K-2 communication iterations. During each iteration, a satellite transmits one segment, which requires only 1K1𝐾\frac{1}{K} of the time needed to transmit the entire model. Consequently, the total time, given by 2​K−2K2𝐾2𝐾\frac{2K-2}{K}, is bounded above by a constant independent of K𝐾K. This implies that the total time required for intra-plane model synchronization remains constant regardless of the increasing scale of the constellation, demonstrating strong scalability.

b) Inter-plane model dissemination. To adapt to the instability of the inter-plane ISLs, a flexible gossip approach is employed to aggregate the locally updated parameters from different orbits. Instead of fully synchronizing all satellite models within orbits as in orbit reduce, DFedSat performs partial model aggregation between orbits by gossip scheme and can flexibly adjust the extent of model diffusion by modifying the gossip round parameter C𝐶C. Specifically, in the gossip round c∈{0,1,…,C−1}𝑐01…𝐶1c\in\{0,1,\ldots,C-1\}, for satellite sm​ksubscript𝑠𝑚𝑘s_{mk} in plane m𝑚m, it receives the model parameters of the left-plane ml=(m−1)%​Msubscript𝑚𝑙percent𝑚1𝑀m_{l}=(m-1)\%M and right-plane mr=(m+1)%​Msubscript𝑚𝑟percent𝑚1𝑀m_{r}=(m+1)\%M satellites and aggregates them:

𝐰m​kt+2/3,c+1superscriptsubscript𝐰𝑚𝑘𝑡23𝑐1\displaystyle\mathbf{w}_{mk}^{t+2/3,c+1} =qm​k,m​kr∗𝐰m​kt+2/3,cabsentsuperscriptsubscript𝑞𝑚𝑘𝑚𝑘𝑟superscriptsubscript𝐰𝑚𝑘𝑡23𝑐\displaystyle=q_{mk,mk}^{r}*\mathbf{w}_{mk}^{t+2/3,c}
+qm​k,ml​kr∗𝐰ml​k→m​kt+2/3,c+qm​k,mr​kr∗𝐰mr​k→m​kt+2/3,c,superscriptsubscript𝑞𝑚𝑘subscript𝑚𝑙𝑘𝑟superscriptsubscript𝐰absent→subscript𝑚𝑙𝑘𝑚𝑘𝑡23𝑐superscriptsubscript𝑞𝑚𝑘subscript𝑚𝑟𝑘𝑟superscriptsubscript𝐰absent→subscript𝑚𝑟𝑘𝑚𝑘𝑡23𝑐\displaystyle+q_{mk,m_{l}k}^{r}*\mathbf{w}_{m_{l}k\xrightarrow{}mk}^{t+2/3,c}+q_{mk,m_{r}k}^{r}*\mathbf{w}_{m_{r}k\xrightarrow{}mk}^{t+2/3,c}, (18)

where 𝐰n​k→m​kt+2/3,rsuperscriptsubscript𝐰absent→𝑛𝑘𝑚𝑘𝑡23𝑟\mathbf{w}_{nk\xrightarrow{}mk}^{t+2/3,r} denotes the model parameters satellite sn​ksubscript𝑠𝑛𝑘s_{nk} transmits to satellite sm​ksubscript𝑠𝑚𝑘s_{mk} and qm​k,n​kr=|𝒟n​k||𝒟ml​k|+|𝒟m​k|+|𝒟mr​k|superscriptsubscript𝑞𝑚𝑘𝑛𝑘𝑟subscript𝒟𝑛𝑘subscript𝒟subscript𝑚𝑙𝑘subscript𝒟𝑚𝑘subscript𝒟subscript𝑚𝑟𝑘q_{mk,nk}^{r}=\frac{|\mathcal{D}_{nk}|}{|\mathcal{D}_{m_{l}k}|+|\mathcal{D}_{mk}|+|\mathcal{D}_{m_{r}k}|} is the inter-plane mixing weight, for n={ml,m,mr}𝑛subscript𝑚𝑙𝑚subscript𝑚𝑟n=\{m_{l},m,m_{r}\}. An example of inter-plane model dissemination with M=5𝑀5M=5 planes is shown in Fig. 4.

After C𝐶C gossip rounds, each orbit has an orbit-personalized model. Similar to (17), the orbit-personalized model vector 𝐖t+1superscript𝐖𝑡1\mathbf{W}^{t+1} can be expressed as

𝐖t+1=𝐐rC​𝐖t+2/3,superscript𝐖𝑡1superscriptsubscript𝐐𝑟𝐶superscript𝐖𝑡23\mathbf{W}^{t+1}=\mathbf{Q}_{r}^{C}\mathbf{W}^{t+2/3}, (19)

where 𝐐r=[qm​k,m​jr]∈ℝK×Ksubscript𝐐𝑟delimited-[]subscriptsuperscript𝑞𝑟𝑚𝑘𝑚𝑗superscriptℝ𝐾𝐾\mathbf{Q}_{r}=[q^{r}_{mk,mj}]\in\mathbb{R}^{K\times K} is the inter-plane mixing matrix.

III-B Model self-compensation for unreliable ISLs

We proceed to consider the general scenario that the exchanged local model parameters in the inter-plane model dissemination phase could fail due to link instability. To address this issue, DFedSat adopts a gossip self-compensation mechanism, where each satellite adaptively compensates for its neighbors’ model parameters using corresponding parts of its local parameters. First, satellite sn​ksubscript𝑠𝑛𝑘s_{nk} partitions its intra-plane synchronized model parameters 𝐰n​kt+2/3superscriptsubscript𝐰𝑛𝑘𝑡23\mathbf{w}_{nk}^{t+2/3} into d𝑑d packets, denoted by 𝐰ˇn​kt+2/3superscriptsubscriptˇ𝐰𝑛𝑘𝑡23\mathbf{\check{w}}_{nk}^{t+2/3}, and transmit them to satellite sm​ksubscript𝑠𝑚𝑘s_{mk}.

Then, satellite sm​ksubscript𝑠𝑚𝑘s_{mk} receives the model packets 𝐰ˇn​k→m​kt+2/3superscriptsubscriptˇ𝐰absent→𝑛𝑘𝑚𝑘𝑡23\mathbf{\check{w}}_{nk\xrightarrow{}mk}^{t+2/3} from satellite sn​ksubscript𝑠𝑛𝑘s_{nk} by unreliable inter-plane ISL:

𝐰ˇn​k→m​kt+2/3=𝐦n​k→m​kt+2/3⊙𝐰ˇn​kt+2/3,superscriptsubscriptˇ𝐰absent→𝑛𝑘𝑚𝑘𝑡23direct-productsuperscriptsubscript𝐦absent→𝑛𝑘𝑚𝑘𝑡23superscriptsubscriptˇ𝐰𝑛𝑘𝑡23\mathbf{\check{w}}_{nk\xrightarrow{}mk}^{t+2/3}=\mathbf{m}_{nk\xrightarrow{}mk}^{t+2/3}\odot\mathbf{\check{w}}_{nk}^{t+2/3}, (20)

where 𝐦n​k→m​kt+2/3superscriptsubscript𝐦absent→𝑛𝑘𝑚𝑘𝑡23\mathbf{m}_{nk\xrightarrow{}mk}^{t+2/3} is a Bernoulli random vector with each element adhering to the Bernoulli distribution with parameter pm​k,n​ksubscript𝑝𝑚𝑘𝑛𝑘p_{mk,nk}. pm​k,n​ksubscript𝑝𝑚𝑘𝑛𝑘p_{mk,nk} denotes the probability of successful transmission between satellite sm​ksubscript𝑠𝑚𝑘s_{mk} and sn​ksubscript𝑠𝑛𝑘s_{nk}. In the gossip self-compensation scheme, the receiver sm​ksubscript𝑠𝑚𝑘s_{mk} detects and sorts the received packets 𝐰ˇn​k→m​kt+2/3superscriptsubscriptˇ𝐰absent→𝑛𝑘𝑚𝑘𝑡23\mathbf{\check{w}}_{nk\xrightarrow{}mk}^{t+2/3}, and then fills the corrupted or lost packets with its own model 𝐰ˇm​kt+2/3superscriptsubscriptˇ𝐰𝑚𝑘𝑡23\mathbf{\check{w}}_{mk}^{t+2/3}:

𝐰^n​k→m​kt+2/3=𝐰ˇn​k→m​kt+2/3+(¬𝐦n​k→m​kt+2/3)⊙𝐰ˇm​kt+2/3.superscriptsubscript^𝐰absent→𝑛𝑘𝑚𝑘𝑡23superscriptsubscriptˇ𝐰absent→𝑛𝑘𝑚𝑘𝑡23direct-productsuperscriptsubscript𝐦absent→𝑛𝑘𝑚𝑘𝑡23superscriptsubscriptˇ𝐰𝑚𝑘𝑡23\hat{\mathbf{w}}_{nk\xrightarrow{}mk}^{t+2/3}=\mathbf{\check{w}}_{nk\xrightarrow{}mk}^{t+2/3}+(\neg\mathbf{m}_{nk\xrightarrow{}mk}^{t+2/3})\odot\mathbf{\check{w}}_{mk}^{t+2/3}. (21)

Fig. 5 is an illustration of model gossip self-compensation scheme of satellites among M=3𝑀3M=3 planes.

It is important to note that the compensated model 𝐰^n​k→m​kt+2/3superscriptsubscript^𝐰absent→𝑛𝑘𝑚𝑘𝑡23\hat{\mathbf{w}}_{nk\xrightarrow{}mk}^{t+2/3} becomes stochastic due to the randomness of 𝐦n​k→m​kt+2/3superscriptsubscript𝐦absent→𝑛𝑘𝑚𝑘𝑡23\mathbf{m}_{nk\xrightarrow{}mk}^{t+2/3}. We can analyze this model diffusion process with a self-compensating mechanism from the perspective of expected values. With this rule, the expectation of orbit-personalized model vector 𝐖t+1superscript𝐖𝑡1\mathbf{W}^{t+1} can be calculated as:

𝔼​{𝐖t+1}=𝔼​{𝐐rC​𝐖t+2/3}=𝔼​{𝐐rC}​𝐖t+2/3,𝔼superscript𝐖𝑡1𝔼superscriptsubscript𝐐𝑟𝐶superscript𝐖𝑡23𝔼superscriptsubscript𝐐𝑟𝐶superscript𝐖𝑡23\mathbb{E}\{\mathbf{W}^{t+1}\}=\mathbb{E}\{\mathbf{Q}_{r}^{C}\mathbf{W}^{t+2/3}\}=\mathbb{E}\{\mathbf{Q}_{r}^{C}\}\mathbf{W}^{t+2/3}, (22)

where 𝔼​{𝐐r}𝔼subscript𝐐𝑟\mathbb{E}\{\mathbf{Q}_{r}\} is defined based on (20) and (21):

𝔼​{𝐐r}:={qm​k,n​kr​pm​k,n​k,m≠n,1−∑k=1,n≠mMqm​k,n​kr​pm​k,n​k,m=n.assign𝔼subscript𝐐𝑟casessubscriptsuperscript𝑞𝑟𝑚𝑘𝑛𝑘subscript𝑝𝑚𝑘𝑛𝑘𝑚𝑛1superscriptsubscriptformulae-sequence𝑘1𝑛𝑚𝑀subscriptsuperscript𝑞𝑟𝑚𝑘𝑛𝑘subscript𝑝𝑚𝑘𝑛𝑘𝑚𝑛\mathbb{E}\{\mathbf{Q}_{r}\}:=\left\{\begin{array}[]{l l}{{q^{r}_{mk,nk}p_{mk,nk},}}&{{m\not=n,}}\\ {{1-\displaystyle\sum_{k=1,n\neq m}^{M}q^{r}_{mk,nk}p_{mk,nk},}}&{{m=n.}}\end{array}\right. (23)

From (22), we can see that aggregating models via unreliable inter-plane ISLs is equivalent to reliable aggregation with the mixing matrix 𝔼​{𝐐r}𝔼subscript𝐐𝑟\mathbb{E}\{\mathbf{Q}_{r}\}.

Remark 2. In the presence of transmission failures, instead of relying on traditional retransmission mechanisms, we utilize the corresponding information from each satellite for compensation. As illustrated in Section V, this gossip self-compensation scheme effectively addresses packet failures, facilitating efficient convergence without significantly increasing overall communication overhead. Moreover, this approach is highly practical for satellite networks with limited resources.

IV Convergence Analysis

In this section, we present the convergence analysis of DFedSat for the general non-convex DFL setting. We begin by introducing the necessary assumptions.

Assumption 1. (L-smoothness). For each satellite sm​k∈𝒩subscript𝑠𝑚𝑘𝒩s_{mk}\in\mathcal{N} and the parameter 𝐰,𝐯𝐰𝐯\mathbf{w},\mathbf{v}, the function fm​ksubscript𝑓𝑚𝑘f_{mk} is differentiable and L𝐿L-smooth, i.e.,

‖∇fm​k​(𝐯)−∇fm​k​(𝐰)‖≤L​‖𝐯−𝐰‖,∀𝐯,𝐰∈ℝdw.formulae-sequencenorm∇subscript𝑓𝑚𝑘𝐯∇subscript𝑓𝑚𝑘𝐰𝐿norm𝐯𝐰for-all𝐯𝐰superscriptℝsubscript𝑑𝑤\|\nabla f_{mk}(\mathbf{v})-\nabla f_{mk}(\mathbf{w})\|\leq L\|\mathbf{v-w}\|,\forall{\mathbf{v,w}}\in\mathbb{R}^{d_{w}}.

The first-order Lipschitz assumption is widely used in decentralized stochastic optimization works [37, 38, 39], reflecting the functions’ smoothness.

Assumption 2. (Uniform bounded local noise). For each satellite sm​k∈𝒩subscript𝑠𝑚𝑘𝒩s_{mk}\in\mathcal{N} and all the parameter 𝐰∈ℝdw𝐰superscriptℝsubscript𝑑𝑤\mathbf{w}\in\mathbb{R}^{d_{w}}, the uniform local variance bound is given as

𝔼​‖∇fm​k​(𝐰,ξ)−∇fm​k​(𝐰)‖≤σ2.𝔼norm∇subscript𝑓𝑚𝑘𝐰𝜉∇subscript𝑓𝑚𝑘𝐰superscript𝜎2\mathbb{E}\|\nabla f_{mk}(\mathbf{w},\xi)-\nabla f_{mk}(\mathbf{w})\|\leq\sigma^{2}.

We assume uniform bounded local noise, as done in many prior works [22],[40],[41]. The uniform local variance is used for the ease of analysis and it is straightforward to generalize to non-uniform cases.

Assumption 3. (Uniform bounded global noise). For each satellite sm​k∈𝒩subscript𝑠𝑚𝑘𝒩s_{mk}\in\mathcal{N}, the uniform global variance bound is given as

1M​K​∑m=1M∑k=1K‖∇fm​k​(𝐰)−∇f​(𝐰)‖≤ζ2.1𝑀𝐾superscriptsubscript𝑚1𝑀superscriptsubscript𝑘1𝐾norm∇subscript𝑓𝑚𝑘𝐰∇𝑓𝐰superscript𝜁2\frac{1}{MK}\sum_{m=1}^{M}\sum_{k=1}^{K}\|\nabla f_{mk}({\bf w})-\nabla f({\bf w})\|\leq\zeta^{2}.

The global variance measures the degree of non-IID data distributions (the heterogeneity of data sets), as used in [42], [43]. If the data across satellites are IID, then the upper bound of the global variance ζ𝜁\zeta is 0.

Based on the assumptions above, we present the following theorem that characterizes the convergence of DFedSat.

Theorem 1. Let Assumptions 1, 2, and 3 hold. Choosing the stepsize η𝜂\eta satisfies 0<η<14​L​I0𝜂14𝐿𝐼0<\eta<\frac{1}{4LI}, then we have

1T​∑t=0T−1𝔼​‖∇f​(𝐰t¯)‖21𝑇superscriptsubscript𝑡0𝑇1𝔼superscriptnorm∇𝑓¯superscript𝐰𝑡2\displaystyle\frac{1}{T}\sum_{t=0}^{T-1}\mathbb{E}\|\nabla f(\overline{{{\mathbf{w}^{t}}}})\|^{2}
≤2​f​(𝐰0¯)−2​f​(𝐰T¯)T​(η​I−α)+β​(η​L2​I+L+L2​α(1−λa​λrC)2)η​I−α,absent2𝑓¯superscript𝐰02𝑓¯superscript𝐰𝑇𝑇𝜂𝐼𝛼𝛽𝜂superscript𝐿2𝐼𝐿superscript𝐿2𝛼superscript1subscript𝜆𝑎superscriptsubscript𝜆𝑟𝐶2𝜂𝐼𝛼\displaystyle\leq\frac{2f(\overline{\mathbf{w}^{0}})-2f(\overline{\mathbf{w}^{T}})}{T(\eta I-\alpha)}+\frac{\beta(\eta L^{2}I+L+\frac{L^{2}\alpha}{(1-\lambda_{a}\lambda_{r}^{C})^{2}})}{\eta I-\alpha}, (24)

where we have defined α=36​η3​L2​I3−36​η2​L​I2𝛼36superscript𝜂3superscript𝐿2superscript𝐼336superscript𝜂2𝐿superscript𝐼2\alpha=36\eta^{3}L^{2}I^{3}-36\eta^{2}LI^{2}, β=6​η2​I2​σ2+18​η2​I2​ζ2𝛽6superscript𝜂2superscript𝐼2superscript𝜎218superscript𝜂2superscript𝐼2superscript𝜁2\beta=6\eta^{2}I^{2}\sigma^{2}+18\eta^{2}I^{2}\zeta^{2}, λasubscript𝜆𝑎\lambda_{a} and λrsubscript𝜆𝑟\lambda_{r} are the second largest eigenvalue of 𝐐asubscript𝐐𝑎\mathbf{Q}_{a} and 𝔼​{𝐐r}𝔼subscript𝐐𝑟\mathbb{E}\{\mathbf{Q}_{r}\} respectively.

Corollary 1. When we choose η=𝒪​(1/L​I​T)𝜂𝒪1𝐿𝐼𝑇\eta=\mathcal{O}(1/LI\sqrt{T}), for a sufficiently large number T𝑇T of training rounds, we can derive an explicit rate from Theorem 1 as follows.

1T​∑t=0T−1𝔼∥∇f​(𝐰t¯)conditional1𝑇superscriptsubscript𝑡0𝑇1𝔼∇𝑓¯superscript𝐰𝑡\displaystyle\frac{1}{T}\sum_{t=0}^{T-1}\mathbb{E}\|\nabla f(\overline{{{\mathbf{w}^{t}}}}) ∥2≤𝒪(f​(𝐰0¯)−f​(𝐰T¯)+ζ2T\displaystyle\|^{2}\leq\mathcal{O}\left(\frac{f(\overline{\mathbf{w}^{0}})-f(\overline{\mathbf{w}^{T}})+\zeta^{2}}{\sqrt{T}}\right.

Remark 3. Our algorithm DFedSat achieves a sub-linear convergence rate in the presence of unreliable links that is equivalent to the convergence rate achieved with reliable links in recent works [23, 24]. We observe that the convergence rate improves when the number I𝐼I of local iterations increases. With a sufficiently large I𝐼I, the local variance diminishes and does not undermine the convergence rate, as each satellite’s parameters approach a local minimizer. Moreover, the bound is dominated by 𝒪​(σ2+I​ζ2(1−λaλrC)2IT3/2))\mathcal{O}\big{(}\frac{\sigma^{2}+I\zeta^{2}}{(1-\lambda_{a}\lambda_{r}^{C})^{2}IT^{3/2})}\big{)} when λa​λrC>1−1Tsubscript𝜆𝑎superscriptsubscript𝜆𝑟𝐶11𝑇\lambda_{a}\lambda_{r}^{C}>1-\frac{1}{\sqrt{T}}. The convergence bound becomes tighter as λasubscript𝜆𝑎\lambda_{a} and λrsubscript𝜆𝑟\lambda_{r} decrease and C𝐶C increases, which are validated in the next section.

V Numerical Results

In this section, we conduct a numerical comparison of the convergence performance of DFedSat with state-of-the-art algorithms, specifically those that adapt DSGD [22], DFedAvg [23], and DFedSAM [23] to the scenarios under study. Additionally, we analyze the robustness of these algorithms and investigate the impact of various system parameters.

V-A Experimental Settings

LEO Constellation Configurations. We examine a Walker-Delta constellation featuring M​K𝑀𝐾MK = 100 LEO satellites distributed across M𝑀M = 10 orbit planes. Satellites within each orbit are equally spaced, with each orbit positioned at an altitude of 604 km and an inclination angle of 143 degrees. The data is transmitted among satellites in 1.2 MB packets. To model packet corruption or loss, we employ randomly generated i.i.d. Bernoulli vectors. The maximum number of retransmissions for the baselines is set to 3. For readers’ convenience, the pertinent parameters of the LEO constellation are summarized in Table I.

Datasets and Models. We conduct experiments on two commonly used datasets, CIFAR-10 [44] and CIFAR-100 [44], focusing on the FL task of image classification. The experiments consider both IID and non-IID data distributions. In the IID setting, the training dataset is randomly distributed across all satellites with equal local dataset sizes, and each satellite has all classes. In the non-IID setting, we employ the Dirichlet partition Dir​(α)Dir𝛼{\rm Dir}(\alpha) with parameters α=0.6𝛼0.6\alpha=0.6 and α=0.3𝛼0.3\alpha=0.3 to represent the data heterogeneity. The backbone model used is ResNet-18, with an initial learning rate of 0.1 and a decay rate of 0.998 per communication round for all experiments. The weight decay is set to 0.001, and a mini-batch size of 64 with a momentum of 0.9 is used. The number of communication rounds is set to 300 for CIFAR-10 and 250 for CIFAR-100.

Baselines. The satellite scenario presents unique challenges compared to the standard decentralized federated learning framework for terrestrial applications. Satellites, acting as clients, typically operate under energy constraints, and communication links are often unstable, particularly for inter-plane ISLs. Given the scarcity of research on decentralized satellite systems, we explore the adaptation of canonical decentralized federated learning algorithms to the satellite scenarios.

∙∙\bullet DSGD: DSGD performs one local update in parallel at each satellite during the local update stage.

∙∙\bullet DFedAvg: This is the decentralized version of FedAvg. Each satellite performs multiple local updates before the communication takes place. The number I𝐼I of the local epoch is set to 5.

∙∙\bullet DFedSAM: Apart from multiple local updates, DFedSAM applies the Sharpness Awareness Minimization (SAM) optimizer at each satellite. The hyperparameter for the perturbation radius ρ𝜌\rho of this SAM optimizer is set to 0.01, consistent with this in [23].

V-B Evaluation of DFedSat’s Convergence Operation

Comparing DFedSat with the baselines. We evaluate the model performance of different algorithms from three key perspectives: convergence performance, communication efficiency, and ISL robustness. To ensure a fair comparison, we set the gossip round C𝐶C to 1, matching the baseline settings.

V-B1 Convergence Performance

As illustrated in Fig. 6LABEL:sub@fig:a and LABEL:sub@fig:b, our proposed algorithm DFedSat outperforms the baselines in terms of both test accuracy and convergence rate in both IID and non-IID settings. The accuracy improvement is more pronounced as the level of heterogeneous data distribution increases (with α𝛼\alpha decreases from 0.6 to 0.3), demonstrating the effectiveness of DFedSat in addressing the statistical heterogeneity. Furthermore, DFedSat exhibits a more noticeable advantage in test accuracy on CIFAR-100 compared to CIFAR-10. This is attributed to DFedSat’s two-phase model aggregation approach, where the inter-plane gossip step leverages intra-plane synchronized model information to enhance the performance of orbit-personalized models. This process effectively provides model information for non-adjacent satellites, further improving performance.

It is noteworthy that DFedAvg and DFedSAM show varying performance rankings on the two datasets under non-IID settings. Specifically, DFedAvg outperforms DFedSAM on CIFAR-10, while DFedSAM outperforms DFedAvg on CIFAR-100. This can be attributed to the SAM optimizer used in DFedSAM, which performs better with complex tasks and heterogeneous data. However, the SAM optimizer may incur more computational overhead as it requires computing the sharpness-aware gradient twice.

V-B2 Communication Efficiency

Fig. 7LABEL:sub@fig:comm-acc-a and LABEL:sub@fig:comm-acc-b illustrate the communication overhead of all algorithms when the test accuracy reaches the target accuracy of 80% (40%) on CIFAR-10 (CIFAR-100) in both IID and non-IID settings. As the heterogeneous data distribution level increases (with α𝛼\alpha decreases from 0.6 to 0.3), the communication overhead also increases. Notably, DFedSat demonstrates a significant advantage in communication efficiency compared to the three benchmarks. Specifically, the communication overhead of DFedSat is approximately 50% of that of DFedAvg and DFedSAM, and only 25% of that of DSGD. This advantage can be attributed to two main factors. First, the convergence speed of DFedSat is faster than the baselines due to the two-stage aggregation, leading to a tighter upper bound of convergence and requiring fewer rounds to reach the target test accuracy. Second, the communication overhead of a single round incurred by DFedSat is lower than the baselines because the model gossip self-compensation scheme effectively mitigates the extra communication overhead of packet retransmission caused by unreliable inter-plane ISLs.

Overall, from Fig. 7LABEL:sub@fig:comm-acc-a and LABEL:sub@fig:comm-acc-b, we can observe the superiority of the proposed model aggregation strategy over conventional strategies. Therefore, DFedSat emerges as a more communication-efficient algorithm while maintaining high accuracy.

V-B3 Unreliable ISL Robustness

Fig. 8LABEL:sub@fig:robust-a and LABEL:sub@fig:robust-b show the test accuracy of each algorithm as transmit power ranging from 0 dBm to 10 dBm. The experimental results show a negligible effect on the performance of DFedSat, whereas the baselines exhibit varying degrees of decrease in test accuracy as the transmit power decreases (implying a weakening of the ISL link stability), thus highlighting the superior robustness of DFedSat.

Fig. 8LABEL:sub@fig:robust-c and LABEL:sub@fig:robust-d show the communication overhead of each algorithm under different transmit power. It should be noted that the communication overhead of DSGD in 0 dBm was not recorded because it failed to reach the target accuracy in the case of poor link quality. Similar to test accuracy, the stability of the ISL link has a negligible effect on the communication overhead because of DFedSat’s model gossip self-compensation mechanism. In contrast, the communication overhead of other baselines keeps increasing with decreasing link stability because of the repeated retransmission of erroneous or lost packets.

Impact of hype-parameters on DFedSat. We conduct an in-depth analysis of how the parameters such as the gossip round C𝐶C and the number of planes M𝑀M in DFedSat influence convergence performance and communication efficiency.

V-B1 The impact of gossip round C𝐶C

Fig. 9LABEL:sub@fig:r-a and LABEL:sub@fig:r-b illustrate the impact of gossip round C𝐶C on test accuracy for the CIFAR-100 dataset under the non-IID setting (α=0.6𝛼0.6\alpha=0.6 and α=0.3𝛼0.3\alpha=0.3). It is observed that larger values of C𝐶C can enhance performance, consistent with our theoretical findings. However, this may also lead to increased communication costs. A comparison between Fig. 9LABEL:sub@fig:r-a and Fig. 9LABEL:sub@fig:r-b reveals that the effect of increasing C𝐶C is more pronounced in scenarios with higher data heterogeneity. This implies that employing a larger C𝐶C value could serve as a beneficial strategy to effectively address the local consistency issue while striking a balance between performance and communication costs.

V-B2 The impact of constellation structure on M𝑀M

We maintain a total of 80 satellites and keep the other constellation parameters constant. As shown in Fig. 10LABEL:sub@fig:M-a, the test accuracy tends to increase as the number of planes M𝑀M decreases (resulting in a higher number of satellites per plane N𝑁N). Intuitively, with fewer planes and a higher density of satellites per plane, each satellite obtains a more comprehensive partially aggregated model. This facilitates broader dissemination of model parameters among satellites in various planes, thereby enhancing overall performance. Remarkably, in a single-plane constellation, DFedSat obviates the need for the gossip dissemination step entirely. From a theoretical standpoint, as illustrated in Fig. 10LABEL:sub@fig:M-b, a smaller number of planes M𝑀M corresponds to a smaller value of λa​λrsubscript𝜆𝑎subscript𝜆𝑟\lambda_{a}\lambda_{r}, resulting in a tighter upper bound of convergence. Our experimental findings align with this theoretical perspective.

VI Conclusion

This paper has proposed DFedSat, a novel decentralized federated learning framework tailored to the LEO constellation. DFedSat has implemented two distinct mechanisms, orbit reduce and gossip dissemination, for intra-plane and inter-plane model exchanges, achieving efficient partial model aggregation. To address unreliable inter-plane model transmission, we have integrated the self-compensation mechanism into DFedSat, reducing communication costs and improving system robustness. Additionally, we have demonstrated the sublinear convergence rate for DFedSat in non-convex scenarios. Extensive experimental results have demonstrated that our algorithm performs competitively in terms of convergence performance, communication efficiency, and robustness to unreliable links, outperforming other DFL baselines

Appendix D Proof of Theorem 1

Proof: Multiplying 𝐘tsuperscript𝐘𝑡\mathbf{Y}^{t} on both sides of (33), we can get 𝐉𝐗t+1=𝐉𝐘tsuperscript𝐉𝐗𝑡1superscript𝐉𝐘𝑡\mathbf{JX}^{t+1}=\mathbf{JY}^{t}, that is

𝐰t+1¯=𝐲t¯.¯superscript𝐰𝑡1¯superscript𝐲𝑡\overline{{{\mathbf{w}^{t+1}}}}={\overline{{{\mathbf{y}^{t}}}}}. (44)

According to the Lipschitz continuity of ∇f∇𝑓\nabla f (Assumption 1), we can get that
